Yet again, Obama proves not to be the gay pride messiah that gay pride proponents thought they were voting for ...
 "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The Obama administration on Friday urged a U.S. court to dismiss a lawsuit by gay married couples from Massachusetts who say they were unlawfully denied federal marriage benefits.
 
 President Barack Obama won strong support from gays during his presidential campaign and has pressed for repealing the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages.
 
 But the gay community has been angered by the Obama administration's defense of the law in court proceedings."http://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSTRE58H57T20090918
 
 Bet you anything the usual apologists here will spin it to try and find some way to still give him the benefit of the doubt.

 But the gay community has been angered by the Obama administration's defense of the law in court proceedings."Obama admin: dismiss gay couple benefits lawsuit | U.S. | Reuters
 
 Bet you anything the usual apologists here will spin it to try and find some way to still give him the benefit of the doubt.

 
 You mean like you try to spin things to try to give REPUBLICANS the benefit of a doubt on gay rights issues where none is deserved? emoticon_rolleyes
 
 It's interesting where you chose to cut-and-paste the article.
 The VERY NEXT STATEMENT includes "the other side of the story"
 Justice Department officials say they are obligated to defend federal statutes when they are challenged.Obama admin: dismiss gay couple benefits lawsuit | U.S. | Reuters
 
 Obama has already put himself on record on his stance on DOMA by VOTING AGAINST it.
 HE PERSONALLY supports its repeal.
 
 But HE PERSONALLY is not "the justice department".
 If a bill is made into law, elected officials can't pick and choose how to do their job and take their personal considerations into account in enforcement.
 I object to people taking it upon themselves to ignore the law when they are county clerks asked to perform gay marriage in areas where it is legal.
 When the courts ruled that Gavin Newsome's gay marriages were illegal and not binding, that was the proper ruling there too.
 
 When it comes to the justice department, it is their job to argue for the existing law. Period.
 
 I don't know why that is so difficult for some.
 I don't know why some pretend a refusal to violate their job position is somehow a demonstration of unmitigated support for what their job requires them to do.

Ah I see. Forget that a given stance is immoral. His administration is just doing what it's supposed to do 'cause it's law .... Forget that it supposedly infringes on rights.
 
 Like I said .... benefit of the doubt. ;)

Ah I see. Forget that a given stance is immoral.

 :xbanghead
 Some practicing Muslims find it "immoral" to wash their hands before surgery.
 What should they do Jyoshu?
 
 They are there to DO A JOB.
 Not to practice their morality.
 
 
 
His administration is just doing what it's supposed to do 'cause it's law .... Forget that it supposedly infringes on rights.
 Like I said .... benefit of the doubt. ;)

 It's amusing how your replies habitually fail to even address the content of people's statements.
 
 Instead of refuting my statements, you are snide.
 Snideness isn't an argument.
 
 The administration IS supposed to do its job.
 The justice department DOES NOT get to pick and choose what laws it wants to defend. It IS NOT the job of the attorneys to ignore laws they don't like.
 OUTSIDE of their justice department role, they can campaign and argue for the law to be changed.
 But when they are ON THE CLOCK and issuing a statement from their justice department position, there is a job that they are supposed to do...
 
 And as for the areas Obama HAS EXPLICITLY shown opposition towards DOMA, you don't even try to refute what I am pointing to.
 Instead, more snideness... emoticon_rolleyes
 
 Snideness is not an argument jyoshu...

Yet again, Obama proves not to be the gay pride messiah that gay pride proponents thought they were voting for ...
 "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The Obama administration on Friday urged a U.S. court to dismiss a lawsuit by gay married couples from Massachusetts who say they were unlawfully denied federal marriage benefits.
 
 President Barack Obama won strong support from gays during his presidential campaign and has pressed for repealing the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages.

 Once again it is better to have the democrats who ignore gay rights then the republicans that want to exterminate gay rights. Or have you forgotten that it is a basic plank in republican party belief systyem to oppose what they call "special rights"

Once again it is better to have the democrats who ignore gay rights then the republicans that want to exterminate gay rights. Or have you forgotten that it is a basic plank in republican party belief systyem to oppose what they call "special rights"

 
 
 It is neither right for EITHER instance MAtthew. Politicians are run by machines and their dirty such as Harvey Milk said. If ANY change is going to come it is from OUR movement with openly gay elected officials. We have put our faith in the democratic party or any politician for that matter for far too long. I personally am disappointed on his lack of action on DADT especially.
 
 The progress we have made in the last 40 years since Stonewall is only because it has been upon the shoulders of a movement of grassroots activism and protest and a unity. Now we have so many splintered factions and cliches within the community that there really is NO community!
 
 Some gays especially A gays don't see the need for activism and are contempt with their own privileged form of second class citizenship. If ANY thing will change it has to be from the US's! No longer can we pander to those who's faith we put into to carry our banner. It has to be done from within.
I do think that Obama has gotten a little spineless on this issue, which I do not like. But Jyoshu - lets not pretend Palin/McCain would have been better advocates.

I do think that Obama has gotten a little spineless on this issue, which I do not like. But Jyoshu - lets not pretend Palin/McCain would have been better advocates.
